column1: Commodore Matthew C. Perry's expeditionary squadron stopped in Naha en route to Tokyo in 1853; and the American ships visited several more times.  The lithographs prepared from drawings made by the expedition's official artist would be widely circulated.  These images would provide the basis for 19th century impressions of the geography and people of the Ryūkyū islands.
After the replacement of the Ryūkyū Kingdom with the Ryūkyū Domain in 1872
column2: Naha became the capital city.  The Ryūkyū Domain was abolished in 1879 and the former Ryūkyū Kingdom came to an end
column3: fully annexed by Japan as Okinawa Prefecture
column4: with Naha remaining as the capital city. Shuri and other neighboring municipalities were absorbed into the city.

column2: Naha suffered extensive damage from the fighting. The entire centre of the city had to be rebuilt. On 1 September 1954
column3: the village of Oroku was merged into the city.On April 1

column1: Naha has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa)—bordering on Tropical rainforest (Köppen climate classification Af)—with hot summers and mild winters. Precipitation is abundant throughout the year; September is the wettest month and December is the driest. Naha has hot and humid summers with July and August being the city's warmest months
column2: exceeding an average high of 31 degrees Celsius. Naha has warm winters
column3: with average high temperatures in the coolest months of January and February
column4: hovering around 19-20 degrees Celsius and average lows around 14-15 degrees Celsius. The city sees a substantial amount of rainfall
column6: 000 mm (79 in) of rain per year.
